name: Maghrebi Music
description: Western region of the Arab world, encompassing the modern countries of Algeria, Libya, Morocco, Tunisia, and the disputed territory of Western Sahara.

children.name: Aita
children.description: Arabic Folk Music from rural Morocco with piercing singing, scratchy viola, and rollicking hand drums.

children.name: Algerian Chaabi
children.description: Features mournful vocals over an orchestral setting of violins, mandolins, pianos, and percussion.

children.name: Andalusian Classical Music
children.description: Arabic Classical Music tradition that had its beginnings in Al-Andalus, the medieval Islamic Iberian peninsula, which later spread and developed in the Maghreb.

children.name: Banga
children.description: Sufi ritual trance music of southern Tunisia performed by Black communities.

children.name: Gnawa
children.description: A mystical musical tradition centred around the qraqab castanets and guembri bass lute, named after its originators, the Afro-Maghrebi Gnawa people.

children.name: Jilala Music
children.description: Music of the Jilala Sufi order, most notably used in healing trance rituals.

children.name: Malhun
children.description: Moroccan sung poetry with instrumental accompaniment.

children.name: Moroccan Chaabi
children.description: Upbeat style of Moroccan popular music played in streets, cafés, weddings, and festivals.

children.name: Raï
children.description: Originated in Algeria in the 1920s as a form of Bedouin Music, blending influences from various rural and urban genres.
